title: 106_s510
content: The Act titled "American Land Sovereignty Protection Act" is established for the purpose of protecting American land sovereignty. The Act "American Land Sovereignty Protection Act" emphasizes Congress's authority over US land use policies, especially in relation to international agreements like the Biosphere Reserve Program. The United States National Man and Biosphere Committee, without congressional authorization, may impact nearby non-Federal lands. State sovereignty and private property rights are crucial in the Federal system, and US actions in designating lands under international agreements can conflict with congressional responsibilities and State capabilities. The Act aims to reaffirm Congress's authority over international agreements concerning US lands, protect State powers, and ensure no loss of individual rights due to Federal actions under such agreements. Federal actions designating lands pursuant to international agreements for imposing restrictions on land use, protecting private property interests, and providing a process for the US to designate lands under international agreements. SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF CONGRESSIONAL ROLE IN WORLD HERITAGE SITE LISTING. Section 401 of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 is amended to restrict the Secretary of the Interior from nominating US-owned lands for the World Heritage List unless commercially viable uses are found for the nominated lands and surrounding areas within 10 miles. The Secretary must ensure that inclusion of nominated lands on the World Heritage List will not adversely affect existing uses, submit a report on natural resources and impacts, and have specific authorization from a post-enactment law. The President may propose legislation for a nomination after a finding is published. The Secretary of the Interior must object to including US properties on the World Heritage in Danger list unless a report on necessity, natural resources, and impacts is submitted to Congress. The Secretary of the Interior can authorize the inclusion of a property on the World Heritage list through a joint resolution of Congress. An annual report on each US World Heritage Site must be submitted, detailing expenses for site management. The annual report for each US World Heritage Site must include an account of expenses, federal hours dedicated to site management, contributions from non-governmental organizations, and a summary of complaints received by the Secretary regarding site management. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION AND TERMINATION OF UNAUTHORIZED UNITED NATIONS BIOSPHERE RESERVES. Title IV of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 prohibits Federal officials from nominating any lands in the United States as a Biosphere Reserve under the Man and Biosphere Program of UNESCO. Any existing designation as a Biosphere Reserve before the enactment of the American Land Sovereignty Protection Act will not have any force unless specifically authorized by a law enacted between the date of enactment and December 31, 2000. The American Land Sovereignty Protection Act prohibits Federal officials from nominating any lands in the United States as a Biosphere Reserve under the Man and Biosphere Program of UNESCO. Existing Biosphere Reserves must be owned by the United States and have a management plan that does not restrict adjacent non-Federal property. International agreements in general are addressed in Section 5. Title IV of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 prohibits Federal officials from nominating, classifying, or designating any lands owned by the United States for special use under international agreements without specific authorization by law. The President can propose legislation for such nominations. State or local government-owned lands also require specific authorization by state law for international agreement nominations. SEC. 6. CLERICAL AMENDMENT. Amends Section 401(b) of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 by changing "Committee on Natural Resources" to "Committee on Resources".
